  • NativeGeometry

setprop NativeGeometry

Sets the geometry of the object to the value. Usage: set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton" to NativeGeometryArray.

setprop NativeGeometry
Description

Use this property to set the NativeGeometry of an object.

NativeGeometryArray format:
- NativeGeometryArray["enabled"] -> Does the object should be resized.
- NativeGeometryArray["relations"] -> NativeGeometry geometry relations. (See later to see how NativeGeometry relations are made).
- NativeGeometryArray["no_auto_resize"] -> Disable the "Auto-resize" feature of NativeGeometry for this object.
- NativeGeometryArray["scale_mode"] -> Scaling mode for this object. Can be "font", "object" or "no".
- NativeGeometryArray["min_width"] -> Minimal width of the object. This property is more important that any other properties!
- NativeGeometryArray["max_width"] -> Maximal width of the object. This property is more important that any other properties!
- NativeGeometryArray["min_height"] -> Minimal height of the object. This property is more important that any other properties!
- NativeGeometryArray["max_height"] -> Maximal height of the object. This property is more important that any other properties!

NativeGeometry Relations

NativeGeometry Geometry relations has been made to be easily understandable by human, this is possible because NativeGeometry has a geometry "compiler" that manage for you all things like geometry resizing order and speed up everything to makes to your users the best experiences using your application.

This section will explain you how to write manually NativeGeometry Relations to be used with NativeGeometry.
Note: By the way, it is recommanded to use the NativeGeometry Revolution Plugins to manage geometry relations.

THE FIRST THINGS THAT YOU MUST KNOW, IS THAT YOU MUST REDUCE TO THE MAXIMUM THE SPEED EXECUTION OF ANY FUNCTIONS THAT WOULD BE CALLED INSIDE A GEOMETRY RELATIONS.
It is because NativeGeometry engine will be called more than hundred of times during a resizing operation, and to have a smooth resizing, nothing should slow down the process. So if you call function that you writed inside NativeGeometry relations make sure that they will be executed as fast as possible to prevent any problems.

Because, a great liberty means great responsability.

So how does NativeGeometryArray["relations"] has to be written ?

-> Well, it is almost like a classic revolution geometry scripts. But it reduces the amount of things to be written.

You can use the following keywords: "me" and "this". (Things not doable inside a resizestack script).

Example of NativeGeometryArray["relations"]:
- I want to set me (I am a button) to the bottom right of this card.
set the right of me to the right of this card
set the bottom of me to the bottom of this card

So, inside the multi-line message box, to set this script do that:
put "set the right of me to the right of this card;set the bottom of me to the bottom of this card" into tArray["relations"]
set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton" to tArray

Note: When you update NativeGeometry properties, only the field updated will be updated. Fields with no value will not be reverted to default in the case where you only want to update geometry relations.

Now, going a bit deeper inside NativeGeometry relations:

- I want to set me (I am still a button) to the bottom of this card, BUT I want to have a space that is dependant of the platform! and I want that too for my right!

NativeGeometry includes the "padding" concept, the padding is a virtual rect located inside card and that is dependant of the platform look and feel!
This is perfect to design cross-platform applications without having to update everything for each platform.

Properties added by NativeGeometry are those ones (Note: usable only inside NativeGeometry relations!):
- <leftPadding> -> The left padding, to set the left of an object.
- <topPadding> -> The top padding, to set the top of an object.
- <rightPadding> -> The right padding, to set the right of an object.
- <bottomPadding> -> The bottom padding, to set the bottom of an object.

This makes this geometry relation:
set the right of me to the rightPadding of this card
set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card

So, inside the multi-line message box, to set this script do that:
put "set the right of me to the rightPadding of this card;set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card" into tArray["relations"]
set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton" to tArray

Going to the perfect cross-platform GUI

- I want to set two buttons at the bottom right of my card, and those two buttons must have a space between them that is dependant of the platform look and feel!

To get the space that must be used between two buttons, there is Padding properties!.
- <leftPadding> -> The left padding, to set the right of an object.
- <topPadding> -> The top padding, to set the bottom of an object.
- <rightPadding> -> The right padding, to set the left of an object.
- <bottomPadding> -> The bottom padding, to set the top of an object.

For the first object, use this geometry relation:
set the right of me to the rightPadding of this card
set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card

And for the second object, use this geometry relation:
set the right of me to the leftPadding of btn "myButton"
set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card

When you look at those two scripts, you see that NativeGeometry will place the first object to the bottom right of the card, and the second object will be placed to the bottom of the card and to the left of the first button, by adding a little space between them that is cross-platform!

So, inside the multi-line message box, to set thoses scripts do that:
put "set the right of me to the rightPadding of this card;set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card" into tArray["relations"]
set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton" to tArray
put "set the right of me to the leftPadding of btn 'myButton'"; set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card" into tArray["relations"]
set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton2" to tArray

The perfect cross platform GUI

In order to have a perfect GUI on all platform, NativeGeometry added "Conditional" geometry relations!

This means that depending one or more conditions, a relation will be executed or not.

- On MacOS X, me (I am a button) I am at the top of the screen, on Windows Vista/Seven, I am on the middle of the screen, on Linux (GTK), I am on the bottom of the screen.

To get the current GUI in use, NativeGeometry has an internal variable called "sLookAndFeel", the value of this variable can be:
- aero The GUI in use is Windows Vista/7 and later...
- winxp The GUI in use is Windows XP.
- win95 The GUI in use is the emulated Windows 95 GUI.
- osX The GUI in use is MacOS X.
- mac The GUI in use is the emulated MacOS Classic GUI.
- gtk The GUI in use is Linux GTK+.
- motif The GUI in use is the emulated Motif GUI.

Also, NativeGeometry allows the use of "if/then/else/else if" !!!!.

This makes this geometry relation:
if sLookAndFeel is among the words of "mac osX" then
set the top of me to the topPadding of this card
else if sLookAndFeel is among the words of "aero winxp win95" then
set the top of me to the height of this card /2 - the height of me /2
else if sLookAndFeel is "gtk motif" then
set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card
end if

Note: What you must remember, is that NativeGeometry has a compiler that will optimize all what you write.

So, inside the multi-line message box, to set this script do that:
put "if sLookAndFeel is among the words of 'mac osX' then;set the top of me to the topPadding of this card;"& &#92;
"else if sLookAndFeel is among the words of 'aero winxp win95' then;set the top of me to the height of this card /2 - the height of me /2;"& &#92;
"else if sLookAndFeel is among the words of 'gtk motif' then;set the bottom of me to the bottomPadding of this card;end if" into tArray["relations"]
set the NativeGeometry of btn "myButton" to tArray

The property "scale_mode"
NativeGeometry 3 introduced the scale method property. This property can have 3 values:
- font Font scaling means that the font of the object will be scaled up/down. (Default)
- object Object scaling means that the font AND the object will be scaled up/down.
- no Disable scaling on the object.

Setting "scale_mode" to "object" will make NativeGeometry scale up/down the font and the object. This is perfect for mobile development.
This scale method circumvent the automatic content adptation of NativeGeometry. (called previously "automatic resize")

The last word
This documentation detailed you how to write NativeGeometry relations, remember that the NativeGeometry compiler is here and will analyzes all your geometry relations in order to discover the best and fatest geometry resizing.

And it is recommanded to use the NativeGeometry Revolution Plugins, to create NativeGeometry geometry relations at the speed of the though ;)

Exceptions
Error CodeDescription
"invalidrelation" The geometry relation is invalid. The first line explain the problem, the second line of the throw error is the line that made the problem.
